roleset.name: call, giving a name
roleset.note: NAME-V NOTES: Based on big corpus, comparison to 'call'. Member of VNcls dub-29.3. (from name.01-v)

roles.note: Essentially equivalent to 'call-v.02', but 'name' Arg2 is 'call' Arg3. (from name.01-v)

example.name: passivized
example.text: [The issue]-1, formally named *trace*-1 MNB Home Equity Loan Asset Backed Certificates, Series 1989, will represent interest in a trust fund...
example.arg: MNB Home Equity Loan Asset Backed Certificates, Series 1989,

example.name: name as AS
example.text: Polls named Tatsunori Hara as the male symbol of Japan.
example.arg: as the male symbol of Japan

example.name: no name mentioned
example.text: ...the man, whom-1 it did not name *trace*-1

example.name: name as infinitive
example.text: Lee Karns named James Nichol to succeed him.

example.name: passivized
example.text: [Both these candidates]-1 are named *trace*-1 Rudolph Giuliani.

example.name: active equivalent of above
example.text: BigHugeCo named John Smith as successor.

example.name: Arg0,1,2
example.text: A last source says that it was because Aina found rest in the area, which occasioned his naming the area as 'Isin.'

roleset.name: give someone else's name
roleset.note: NAME-V NOTES: Very similar to name.01, and only to be used when there is an 'after' present. Member of VNcls dub-29.3. (from name.02-v)

example.name: ozone hole
example.text: As an employee of a major refrigerator and freezer manufacturer, I have been heavily involved in dealing with the political manifestations of [the Rowland-Molina theory]-1 (named [*]-1 after the researchers who found in 1974 that chlorofluorocarbons contributed to the depletion of ozone in the earth's atmosphere) and the Montreal Protocol.
example.arg: after the researchers who found in 1974 that chlorofluorocarbons contributed to the depletion of ozone in the earth's atmosphere

roleset.name: to appoint to an office, assign a role
roleset.note: NAME-V NOTES: Roleset for 'name' appoint sense based on instances in Webtext 2.5, section 76-199. VerbNet class appoint-29.1. Comparison to 'appoint.' Framed by Claire (from name.03-v)

example.name: Job with 'to' preposition
example.text: *PRO*-1 Having campaigned for the new president and been named *-1 to his transition team , [Rumsfeld]-1 told his Searle sales force , according to later testimony , that `` he would call in all his markers and that no matter what , he would see to it that aspartame would be approved *-3 . ''
